text: hey everyone
Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest
music nerd and it's time for a review of
the new primal scream album more light
these guys are a Glasgow rock band
they've been releasing material since
the late 80s late mid 80s and this new
record of theirs is another addition to
their ever-growing discography in which
there are a few major highlights like
Screamadelica and 91 exterminator in
2000 and this band's career has really
been defined by almost always being in
some sort of state of flux Primal
Scream's albums can be mixed bags from
time to time but their best and and some
of their longest releases are undeniably
cohesive and for sure this new album of
there's more light is one of their more
cohesive ones as of late I think it's
one of their better records as of late
it's one of their longer ones - if not
the longest album period and Primal
Scream's records that break that
60-minute mark do tend to be some of
their better ones now for one the band
is getting back to their more
psychedelic side the more psychedelic
side of their sound with numerous songs
on here being really thick noisy heavy
with instrumentation very repetitive
with riffs that that are just grooved
out to the point of being a little
hypnotic and I think this is one of
their more consistent records - with how
much the band sticks to some of these
more psychedelic and just trippy sounds
this LP is just overwhelming with sound
and momentum and and rock-and-roll
swagger and it can be pretty impressive
instrumentally as well bringing together
rock instrumentation blending it with
strings with horns of course this is not
the only vibe that the band channels on
this record
you've got the buzzing walls of guitar
and the blaring sax riffs on the opening
track 2013 you've got acoustics on here
backed with some sitar hard distorted
riffs against some very sharp drumbeats
song hit void brings a really shoegaze
evite to these very just wavy wavy
warped guitars their tracks on here the
features some very strange
see echoes and The Closer on here
features Bobby Gillespie singing over
what what feels like some kind of
long-lost gospel chorus backed Rolling
Stones instrumental it's a little hokey
but it is fun it's a really big change
of pace from the urgent opening track on
this LP that talks about just the media
propaganda rock and roll
the only other track that sticks out to
me is not being incredibly psychedelic
but still is another favorite of mine on
this thing is the track invisible City
with its very just hard grooving
bassline that that to me feels like the
band is really getting back to their
more alternative dance side of course
there are some very peppy horns
throughout this track too and it's got
one of the sharper choruses on this
thing even though it is short it's very
catchy if there is one thing though that
that I didn't really care for throughout
this LP it to get a little old to me it
is Bobby's vocals at times there are
moments when I wish he was as passionate
as he was on the closer the sort of
breathy approach that he makes to a lot
of the songs on this album can get a
little stale and makes these songs feel
say me say me at times the only other
issue that I have is that is that some
of these songs with this album being
very long can feel overly long
elimination blues tenement kid I think
the vocal melodies on these tracks are a
little too repetitive as are the lyrics
they feel a little too surface level for
me the track goodbye Johnny - suffers
from this issue and on top of it just
the the vocal delivery and the lyrics
feels a little corny compared this track
this slower track with another slow
track on here walking with the beast
which is very pretty beautiful guitar
melody on this track it's a little
Velvet Underground esque and and to me
one of the more moving songs on this
album I can really tell lyrically Bobby
Gillespie is is struggling with
something in in what he is saying and at
least while he is putting down into
words yeah he's breathy again on this
track but with what he is saying it
feels like a very personally painful
track overall I did think a few of the
tracks on this LP were underwhelming
sure but for an album this long
that was never a point at which I was
sitting there and I really felt like I
wanted it to end I was always in a
position where I was just waiting for
what the band was gonna throw at me next
and in retrospect even though an album
like that can get kind of old because
once you learn its intricacies it's you
know you know them it's whatever it's
not a surprise anymore I still ended up
pretty pleased with with how this LP
came out what my listening experience
with it was this record is not one of my
favorites of this year but I do think it
is possibly the best the band has put
out since exterminator so do take that
into account if you've given this LP oh
listen what did you think of it did you
love it hate it why what do you think I
should review next and that's it Anthony
Fantan Oh primal scream more light
